title: I am very good at creative writing and I want to pursue it as a career. How can I go ahead? - Quora

response.answer_text: First off, stop thinking of it as a career in creative writing. Your major options are a career in writing, or a career in teaching. I suppose editing would be a third possibility. You do not need to study “creative writing” for any of those. If you intend to teach creative writing, it’s probably useful, but otherwise it’s completely unnecessary. I know dozens of professional writers, and none of them have degrees in creative writing. Most, including myself, never even took a course in creative writing. We do not think of what we do as creative writing, we just think of it as writing, even though yes, it’s creative. “Creative writing” is something students do for a cheap grade. To develop a writing career, you need to narrow it down to a specific sort of writing initially. (You can branch out again once you’re established.) Do you want to write novels, essays, short stories? Which sort? For essays and nonfiction, you aim at journalism. For short stories, well, you can’t make a living writing short stories, so you get a teaching job in literature and write short stories on the side. For novels, you just write a novel on your own and sell it to a respectable publisher, then build from there.

I believe one should start with writing short stories and then with practice progress to novellas and novels. One need not be a novel writer to be known as an author. One can write short stories, essays and poems to be a big shot.Do not be ashamed if your story matches with the works of great writers, coz that's how it works. Without one speck of fire, you can't kindle a large one. Slowly you would see your works getting more originality as you improve your writings. As a result of what they do, you will have better soft skills, personality and gain relevant experience that will make you more employable.
